TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit ErrorWebPart extends System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ProxyWebPart implements class System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ITrackingPersonalizable
Public Class ErrorWebPart Inherits ProxyWebPart Implements ITrackingPersonalizable
type ErrorWebPart = class inherit ProxyWebPart interface ITrackingPersonalizable

Docs.summary: Inserted into a Web page as a placeholder when the attempt to load or create a new instance of a dynamic control has failed.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ErrorWebPart> class is used by the Web Parts control set as a placeholder for a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> control that could not be added to the page. If the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartManager> control attempts to load or create a new instance of a dynamic <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> control in a zone, and the attempt fails for some reason, the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartManager> then calls the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartManager.CreateErrorWebPart%2A> method, and inserts an <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ErrorWebPart> control in place of the control that failed.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ErrorWebPart> control is inserted to preserve previously existing personalization state information that might have existed on a control for users. For example, suppose there is a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> control that has a personalizable property, so that users can save their own ZIP Code, and then the control can automatically display weather information for that ZIP Code each time the user visits the page. If at some point a problem occurs with the weather control so that it cannot be loaded during a specific request, and yet the rest of the page does load successfully, the custom personalization data that a user has saved for that control would be lost the next time the personalization data for the page is saved. By inserting the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ErrorWebPart> control in place of the failed control, you can notify the user that a problem has occurred, and also provide a mechanism for the Web Parts control set to preserve the user's personalization data on the failed control until the problem can be corrected.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ErrorWebPart> class derives from the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ProxyWebPart> class, as one of several types designed to be temporary placeholders for other types. To create an instance of the class, the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartManager> control uses its public <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ErrorWebPart.%23ctor%2A> constructor. The constructor requires several details of the failed control to be passed to it, such as the ID, the original type of the control (if the failed control is a server or user control wrapped in a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.GenericWebPart> object), the original path to the source file for the control (if the failed control is a user control), and the ID of a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.GenericWebPart> object if present.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ErrorWebPart> class has a single public property called <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ErrorWebPart.ErrorMessage%2A>. Developers can assign a value to this property that will be displayed in a Web page when the control is inserted.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ErrorWebPart> class has three protected methods. The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ErrorWebPart.AddAttributesToRender%2A> method takes style characteristics from the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebZone.ErrorStyle%2A> object for the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebZone> zone that contains the control that failed to load. If any style settings exist in this object, the method applies them to the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ErrorWebPart> control. The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ErrorWebPart.EndLoadPersonalization%2A> method sets several important inherited properties on the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ErrorWebPart> control, to prevent users from personalizing the control by hiding, minimizing, editing, or exporting it, or changing its <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.Part.ChromeState%2A> value. Finally, the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ErrorWebPart.RenderContents%2A> method encodes the value of the string in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ErrorWebPart.ErrorMessage%2A> property, to prevent rendering problems or scripting attacks.

block.para:
The conditions in which an control is actually inserted into a page are relatively rare, and although the class can be inherited from and extended, few developers will find this to be of great importance. One reason you might want to extend this class is if you want to customize the appearance and behavior of the control. For example, you could override the method, and set additional style or other properties on the control, beyond those that are already set.
To require the control to use a custom control, you must also inherit from the class and override its method. In that method, you should assign the value of the method's parameter to the property of your custom control, because the control calls this method from several other places, and often passes in a different error message value.

MemberSignature.Value: public ErrorWebPart (string originalID, string originalTypeName, string originalPath, string genericWebPartID);
.method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(string originalID, string originalTypeName, string originalPath, string genericWebPartID) cil managed
Public Sub New (originalID As String, originalTypeName As String, originalPath As String, genericWebPartID As String)
public: ErrorWebPart(System::String ^ originalID, System::String ^ originalTypeName, System::String ^ originalPath, System::String ^ genericWebPartID);

Attribute.AttributeName: System.Runtime.TargetedPatchingOptOut("Performance critical to inline this type of method across NGen image boundaries")

Docs.param: A string that is the control ID (not the unique ID) of the failing control. If a control is involved in the failure, the ID is the ID of its child server control.
A string that is the name of the of the failed control. If a control is involved in the failure, the type name is the type of its child server control.
A string that contains the path to a user control, if a control that contains a child user control is involved in the failure.
A string that returns the ID of a control, if that type of control was involved in the failure to load or create a control. This is needed for controls that do not inherit from the base class.
Docs.summary: Initializes a new instance of the control.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartManager> control creates a new instance of the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ErrorWebPart> control when it fails in an attempt to load or create an instance of a dynamic <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> control. Dynamic controls are controls that are added to a page programmatically, or by a user who adds the control from a catalog of controls, as opposed to static controls that are declared in the markup of a Web page.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ErrorWebPart.%23ctor%2A> method simply creates an instance of the base class, passing to it the four parameters that contain information about the failed control.

MemberSignature.Value: .method familyhidebysig virtual instance void AddAttributesToRender(class System.Web.UI.HtmlTextWriter writer) cil managed
Protected Overrides Sub AddAttributesToRender (writer As HtmlTextWriter)

Docs.param: An that contains the HTML output to be rendered.
Docs.summary: Applies special error style attributes to an object that is inserted into a page in place of another control.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ErrorWebPart.AddAttributesToRender%2A> method takes the style characteristics (if any) that are defined in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebZone.ErrorStyle%2A> object for the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebZone> zone that contains an <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ErrorWebPart> control. The styles are applied to the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ErrorWebPart> control prior to rendering.

block.para:
This method can be overridden in a derived class, if developers want to customize the style characteristics that are applied to an control.
To require the control to use a custom control, you must also inherit from the class and override its method. In that method, you should assign the value of the method's parameter to the property of your custom control, because the control calls this method from several other places, and usually passes in a specific error message.

MemberSignature.Value: .method familyhidebysig newslot virtual instance void EndLoadPersonalization() cil managed
abstract member EndLoadPersonalization : unit -> unit override this.EndLoadPersonalization : unit -> unit

Docs.summary: Sets several important properties on the control prior to rendering, to prevent users from being able to personalize the control.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ErrorWebPart.EndLoadPersonalization%2A> method sets properties on an <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ErrorWebPart> control before it is rendered. These properties prevent users from hiding, minimizing, editing, or exporting the control, or changing its <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.Part.ChromeState%2A> value. However, users can close or delete an <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ErrorWebPart> control instance.

block.para:
This method can be overridden in an inherited control. Developers might want to override the method to set additional properties on the control, such as a default property value.
To require the control to use a custom control, you must also inherit from the class and override its method. In that method, you should assign the value of the method's parameter to the property of your custom control, because the control calls this method from several other places, and usually passes in a specific error message.

MemberSignature.Value: public: property System::String ^ ErrorMessage { System::String ^ get(); void set(System::String ^ value); };
member this.ErrorMessage : string with get, set

Attribute.AttributeName: set: System.Runtime.TargetedPatchingOptOut("Performance critical to inline this type of method across NGen image boundaries")

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the error message that is displayed in a Web page in place of a control that could not be successfully added to the page.
Docs.value: A string that contains the text of the error message. The default value is a culture-specific error message.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ErrorWebPart.ErrorMessage%2A> property can be assigned a value by a developer, so that a custom error message is displayed at the point where the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ErrorWebPart> control is inserted into a page.

block.para:
Developers can assign a default value to the property by extending the class and, in the constructor or in an overridden method, assigning a default value to the property.
To require the control to use a custom control, you must also inherit from the class and override its method. In that method, you should assign the value of the method's parameter to the property of your custom control, because the control calls this method from several other places, and usually passes in a specific error message.

MemberSignature.Value: protected internal override void RenderContents (System.Web.UI.HtmlTextWriter writer);

Protected Friend Overrides Sub RenderContents (writer As HtmlTextWriter)

Docs.param: An that encodes the error message.
Docs.summary: Encodes the string value of the property.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ErrorWebPart.RenderContents%2A> method encodes the string assigned to the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ErrorWebPart.ErrorMessage%2A> property to ensure that it renders properly, and to protect against script injection attacks.
